text: Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Everybody. Family Member: Not me, but yeah, them. Doctor: Right. Everybody that, so, you have one, it’s, it’s a mutation in the gene. You have two copies of the gene. It’s, you know, so there’s a one and four chance you could pass it on because two copies come from your, their mother, and so, the mother contributes one, you contribute one. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: There’s a fifty/fifty chance, you could contribute a good one or bad one, so they -- you know – does that make sense? Patient: Right. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah I know all of that. Doctor: So -. Family Member: Does insurance do anything with this? I mean, do they consider you a risk? Are you -- Doctor: I don’t know. Um, you, you, they’re going to need to talk with their doctors. I do know that the test we did, I think, allows, if we, a discounted test, I’ll find out --- for family members, um, to test as well. Um, there is just a test for BRCA, and then there’s a, you know, at this point these tests are, cover about thirty different genes. Um. That’s the only one they found. So, for your family, I think it, it requires a discussion about it, and then they should – you know, they need to make a decision if they want to get tested or not. Um. It’s a risk factor for prostate and breast. So, and ovarian, so both sons and daughters, and then, you know, their sons and daughters if they – I would say if they were positive. If they were negative, there’s – you know, your grandkids are – it, it can’t skip over it – so, if your sons or daughter is negative (coughs) Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Unless their – Family Member: Their husband has it –

text: Patient: I feel so; I, I uh I govern that by my ability to you know do things around the house. So whether it’s supporting activities, playing golf I don’t have any energy. And possibly because I’m a little heavier now, too. I’ve gained a few pounds. Doctor: Now are you still trying to be as active as possible, for example, golf or other activities? Or has that been slowing you down? Patient: I’m trying, but I just don’t have the energy. Doctor: Okay, uh any other issues with hot flashes or night sweats? Patient: No, no. Not night sweats, but I do recognize that at times I’m sitting in church and for some reason I just start where other folks are you know are just perfectly calm and cool. Doctor: So during the day just out of the blue? Patient: Yeah, just out of the blue. It last for a few minutes and then stops. Doctor: Okay, on an average day how many times does that happen or is it not every day? Patient: When I’ve noticed it, it might be once or twice a day. Doctor: Okay, all right. Usually not at night, usually during the day. Patient: No, no. Well it could be the stress or the activity that’s happening in church that might push my level. Doctor: Well your testosterone level is still low. Patient: Uh hum.

text: Patient: Now I’ve got a question for you. Doctor: Yeah. Shoot. Patient: Nobody really explained to me what I will feel as this disease progresses- Doctor: Mmm. Patient: -as it changes and that I will detect the symptoms that I will. Doctor: Yeah. Well, the sheer fact that you are actually asking me that tells me that you don't have many symptoms, because people who have the symptoms, be it bone pain or just extreme fatigue or weight Loss, no appetite will tell me, “Oh man, look at all these things happening to me is because of my cancer?” So when you're curious, that means like, okay, none of this stuff is happening, which is great, but you worry about it because you think this is it, I'm gonna get bone pain. And this is it. You know, that's not the case. If you have pain in the bone, there are medicines to help or more importantly, there are techniques like radiation to help and there are other medicines that we can do to and other strategies to help the pain go away. So pain is usually what everybody worries about is number one, and then the other ones would be things like, you know, complete quality of life loss is, “I don't want to anything” Patient: Yeah I quit Lupron for that reason. Doctor: And you're just like, oh, man, I can't do it. Patient: So, what was the other doctor’s name? Doctor: J____. Family Member: J____. Patient: He asked about Lupron. He said Aligard. I said it’s the same thing. It’s not.

text: Family Member: Fifth. Doctor: Fifth? We would need to, again, hold the drug. Because even at the lower dose of two-fifty, it’s still causing, you know, that significant anemia. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, I just want to get a sense from you whether you think you might, you know, want to stick with this for about two more months until the next set of scans? Whether you feel that you’ve had enough and you want to try something new? Or like where are you at with this? Patient: Well- Family Member: So, can I give you my perspective-? Doctor: Yeah. Please. Yes. Family Member: Of how I see it going? And then he can correct me if I’m wrong. But I feel like, um, D___ is in pain often, and, um, it’s, I would say the past two weeks, I would say like maybe last week, maybe a week and a half ago, he was in a lot of pain and very weak, from my perspective, what I am seeing. And, um, so often, and often would mean almost nightly, I am rubbing him with either Salonpas or Aspercreme or Bengay, one of the three, on his back, shoulders, legs, so that he can feel comfortable enough so he can lay down and rest. So, you know, that’s how I see it. I don’t know if he feels, if maybe I’m interpreting his pain to be more than it is, but when he asks me to rub, you know, rub something on his back, in my mind it’s pain. When I look at his face, I see that he’s in pain. So that’s what I see. And, you know, it might be that he’s like no, P___, it’s not that bad. On a scale of one to ten, it might be seven, but when I look at him, I’m seeing eight, nine. Doctor: We’ve got a thing to keep in mind is in your case we decided to try this study because of the genetic mutations that your tumor had. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it wasn’t that we tried this study because you had exhausted all other options. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the reason we’re saying that is because there are other things out there that your cancer has a good chance of responding well to. For example, uh, the alternative hormone therapy called Xtandi, that you have not received. You have received the one called, Zytiga. But there’s a similar one that was FDA approved about a year after the Zytiga was approved, called Xtandi. And it’s an oral hormone therapy pill. That medication does not work that well after people have received Zytiga first because it’s similarly related to that drug, but that’s an option. The second option is intravenous chemotherapy, which you have also not received. Um, which I know that you have been reluctant to think about it in the past, but that clearly is an option. So you have a minimum of two FDA-approved options that you have not tried yet. So knowing that, um, from my perspective, like I’m going to be a little less sort of heroic and like waiting to see if this is going to work or not. Because it’s not like you’ve run out of options, and this is the last thing we’re going to try anyway. You know? There are other options out there. Because we do have those options, yes, one of them is a chemo. Um, we also don’t want this cancer to advance too quickly that we miss the window and you get too sick and too frail, you know, to be able to tolerate those other therapies.

So, you know, that’s how I see it. I don’t know if he feels, if maybe I’m interpreting his pain to be more than it is, but when he asks me to rub, you know, rub something on his back, in my mind it’s pain. When I look at his face, I see that he’s in pain. So that’s what I see. And, you know, it might be that he’s like no, P___, it’s not that bad. On a scale of one to ten, it might be seven, but when I look at him, I’m seeing eight, nine. Doctor: We’ve got a thing to keep in mind is in your case we decided to try this study because of the genetic mutations that your tumor had. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it wasn’t that we tried this study because you had exhausted all other options. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the reason we’re saying that is because there are other things out there that your cancer has a good chance of responding well to. For example, uh, the alternative hormone therapy called Xtandi, that you have not received. You have received the one called, Zytiga. But there’s a similar one that was FDA approved about a year after the Zytiga was approved, called Xtandi. And it’s an oral hormone therapy pill. That medication does not work that well after people have received Zytiga first because it’s similarly related to that drug, but that’s an option. The second option is intravenous chemotherapy, which you have also not received. Um, which I know that you have been reluctant to think about it in the past, but that clearly is an option. So you have a minimum of two FDA-approved options that you have not tried yet. So knowing that, um, from my perspective, like I’m going to be a little less sort of heroic and like waiting to see if this is going to work or not. Because it’s not like you’ve run out of options, and this is the last thing we’re going to try anyway. You know? There are other options out there. Because we do have those options, yes, one of them is a chemo. Um, we also don’t want this cancer to advance too quickly that we miss the window and you get too sick and too frail, you know, to be able to tolerate those other therapies.

text: Patient: So I think I'll stay the course and then we'll see what happens after that. Because I'm pretty good watching. If anything is swelling or if I’m having any pain. I'll be a little more vigilant now to go to the doctor whereas before I'm like. Doctor: Hopefully it doesn’t happen while you’re on the medicine. Patient: Right, no, I'm saying if I got off of it, I'd be a little more vigilant about the idea that if I have swelling, I should go to the doctor because it might not just be me being a macho jock, but I have a problem. Doctor: And so what I hear you say- is that you just got a prescription and how long is that going to be for? Patient: I think that's for three more months. Doctor: So that would be your plan to sort of go and then stop for six months. Healthcare Professional: Okay Patient: Yeah. That works for me. Doctor: Yeah. Blood work, Aximun scan. You're not on MyChart? Patient: I tried to get on MyChart, but the little number that he sent me, died or whatever. Doctor: Yeah, but I can we can print out a new one for you today. Patient: Okay good. Doctor: And then if you can just MyChart message me your email-

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
